LEAD: International
International

The U.S. and the European Community took a step toward settling their differences on farm subsidies. How big a step was not certain, as the two sides agreed to establish a framework for negotiations by year-end but did not specify what the framework would be. U.S. officials said they were satisfied with the outcome of the two-day talks in Paris. [ Page D1. ] The European Community and Comecon are close to establishing official relations. [ D2. ]
Treasury Secretary Baker wants to refine coordination of the system of floating exchange rates. [ D2. ] Markets

Alan Greenspan strongly endorsed program trading and stock-index arbitrage, two controversial stock trading strategies. The chairman of the Federal Reserve told a Congressional committee, ''It is a mistake to single out one segment of the broad marketplace as the culprit for large and rapid price movements.'' [ D1. ]

Stock prices ended mixed despite a sharp rebound in the blue chips. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.63 points, to close at 1,958.72, after being sharply lower early in the day. But more stocks fell in value than gained. [ D6. ]
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher, breaking a three-day slide. The price rise occurred despite a sharp increase in commodity prices. [ D12. ]
The dollar drifted lower against most major currencies except the mark and the British pound. Gold rose 10 cents on the Comex, to $457.40 an ounce. [ D13. ]
Soybean and grain futures were hit by a surge of buying, lifting all expiring spot May soybeans and soybean products to contract highs. Wheat and corn posted sharp gains. [ D13. ]
Shares sold short and not yet covered rose 4.8 percent on the Big Board and 5.1 percent on the American Exchange for the month ended last Friday. [ D14. ] The Economy

The F.S.L.I.C. will need a new capital infusion to bail out the growing number of insolvent savings and loans, the Government Accounting Office said. More than 500 savings institutions are in distress, the G.A.O. said. [ D1. ]

A way to burn coal more cleanly, with much lower emissions of two components of acid rain, would be used in a full-size electric plant for the first time under a proposal made by American Electric Power, one of the nation's largest utilities. [ D1. ]
A continued erosion in national advertising will hurt television and radio for the rest of the year, Capital Cities/ABC said. [ D14. ] Companies

Neither Bank of New York nor Irving is backing down as deadlines near for Bank of New York's takeover offers. A revised offer that is conditional on Irving's board agreeing to a merger expires today. [ D1. ]
SmithKline Beckman will invest $49 million in Nova, a small research-oriented drug company. Nova is working on a new cold remedy and other drugs. [ D1. ]
Ivan F. Boesky, his wife and Drexel Burnham Lambert must receive part of the proceeds from any liquidation of a partnership formed by Mr. Boesky, a Delaware court ruled. [ D4. ]
Texaco is leaning toward a stock buyback and away from selling to its shareholders its stake in Texaco Canada, according to participants in its talks with Carl C. Icahn. [ D5. ]
Drexel Burnham Lambert is very unhappy with a book to be published by Simon & Schuster and The American Lawyer. [ D14. ] Today's Columns
The stock market has grown hypersensitive to the trade statistics, and it does not like what it sees, whether the deficit goes up or down. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
Farmers Group is resorting to an unusual defense against the hostile takeover by Batus. Market Place. [ D6. ]
